SEARCH
Package org.loudouncodes.combinatorics

Class Combinations

java.lang.Object
org.loudouncodes.combinatorics.Combinations
All Implemented Interfaces:
Iterable<int[]>
public class Combinations extends Object implements Iterable<int[]>
Generates all k-combinations (unordered, without repetition) from the integer domain {0, 1, ..., n-1} in lexicographic order and exposes them via Java's enhanced for loop by implementing Iterable<int[]>.

What is a combination?

A k-combination of n elements is a size-k subset, where order does not matter and no element is repeated. For example, with n = 5 and k = 3, one combination is [0,2,4] (the same as the set {0,2,4}).

Order of generation (lexicographic)

We emit strictly increasing arrays of length k. For example: 


 new Combinations(3, 5)  // n = 5, k = 3
 -> [0,1,2], [0,1,3], [0,1,4], [0,2,3], [0,2,4], [0,3,4],
    [1,2,3], [1,2,4], [1,3,4], [2,3,4]

Algorithm (lexicographic successor / "odometer" carry)

Maintain the current combination current[0..k-1] as a strictly increasing sequence. To advance to the next combination:

  1. Start at the rightmost index i = k-1 and move left while current[i] == n - k + i (i.e., that position is at its maximum).
  2. If no such i exists, we are past the last combination (set hasNext = false).
  3. Otherwise, increment current[i]++, and then reset the suffix to the smallest increasing sequence: current[i+1] = current[i] + 1, current[i+2] = current[i+1] + 1, etc.

This is identical in spirit to an odometer with different digit limits per position.

Correctness intuition

  • Exhaustiveness: Starting at [0,1,...,k-1] and repeatedly applying the successor rule enumerates every strictly increasing k-tuple until no index can be increased.
  • No duplicates: The state is deterministic; each successor is unique and monotone in lexicographic order.
  • Ordering: We increase the earliest position possible and reset the suffix minimally, yielding standard lexicographic order over increasing k-tuples.

Complexity

  • Time per combination: O(k) (short left-scan and suffix reset).
  • Total combinations: C(n,k) = n! / (k! (n-k)!) â€” available via size().
  • Space: O(k) internal state. Each call to Iterator.next() returns a defensive copy so callers can safely mutate their copy without affecting iteration.

Edge cases

  • k == 0: a single empty array [] is emitted.
  • k == n: a single array [0,1,...,n-1] is emitted.
  • Invalid inputs (negative, or k > n) throw IllegalArgumentException.

Example


 Combinations combos = new Combinations(3, 12);
 System.out.println("Total: " + combos.size());
 for (int[] c : combos) {
     System.out.printf("[%d, %d, %d]%n", c[0], c[1], c[2]);
 }

Implementation note: Each next() clones the internal array to preserve iterator integrity.

Since:
0.1.0

    • Combinations

      public Combinations(int k, int n)
      Constructs a generator of k-combinations from {0..n-1}.
      Parameters:
      k - size of each combination (must satisfy 0 <= k <= n)
      n - size of the ground set (n >= 0)
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if k < 0, n < 0, or k > n

  • Method Details

    • size

      public long size()
      Returns the total number of k-combinations of n items (the binomial coefficient).
      Returns:
      C(n,k) as a long

    • iterator

      public Iterator<int[]> iterator()
      Returns a fresh iterator positioned at the first combination [0,1,...,k-1] (or the empty array if k == 0).

    • main

      public static void main(String[] args)
      Small demo for quick sanity checks. Prints all combinations for k = 3, n = 12. This is not used by the library and may be removed in production builds.
